attributes.action: Prohibit removal or destruction of any wildlife and habitat from private land
attributes.background: Call for the Government to amend the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 to prohibit the removal or destruction of any wildlife and habitat from private land. A full ecological survey of any site should be carried out prior to work starting.
attributes.additional_details:
This should close the existing loophole where a planning application is required before authorities check for existing wildlife. A full ecological survey of any site where potential developments are planned should be required.

I would hope this would prevent the destruction of wildlife and habitat before anyone knows what is there.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Protect our wildlife - ban driven grouse shooting
attributes.background:
Upland wildlife is being poisoned, burned, trapped and shot by rogue gamekeepers attempting to keep Red Grouse numbers artificially high so that a few wealthy individuals can blast them out of the sky in the name of sport!

Shooting is economically insignificant when compared to wildlife tourism.
attributes.additional_details:
For too long government has chosen to ignore the plight of our wildlife on our upland areas, due to the lobbying of wealthy land owners and shooting organisations.

We want the Government to finally introduce a total ban on the driven shooting of Red Grouse. For too long the industry has ignored the pleas from conservationists to bring their house in order and stop these rogue gamekeepers from slaughtering our wildlife. Our raptors such as Golden Eagles and Hen Harriers deserve better protection.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase financial support for UK zoos this winter (September until Easter)
attributes.background:
UK zoos, aquariums, wildlife parks and animal sanctuaries are under threat of closure. They need confirmation they will be financially supported, if necessary, until Easter 2021 (when, hopefully, they can return to a normal busy season).
 
We have already lost one zoo (Living Coasts) due to COVID.
attributes.additional_details:
Firstly, thank you to the Government for increasing the funding available to zoos from £14m to £100m, it is very welcome. But the limits on claims by individual zoos, and total amount of money available, is not sufficient. These restrictions could see zoos close. 
 
The Government should increase financial support for UK zoos, and remove restrictions on claims by individual zoos.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require wildlife crossings to be added to all roads
attributes.background: Roads contribute to declining biodiversity. As an example, roads put pressure on barn owl numbers in certain areas as a result of deaths caused by vehicle strikes. Bats can be affected by road lighting at night and insect pollinators are affected by pollution and poor management of grass verges.
attributes.additional_details:
The Highways England Biodiversity plan proposes to include at least five measures to maximise habitat connectivity, linking road verges and associated land with the wider landscape wherever possible. This will include consideration of measures to improve connectivity across roads, which might include green bridges and/or tunnels.

We would love our wildlife to be able to cross roads safely, this will lead to fewer car accidents and increased biodiversity and wildlife in the United Kingdom.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban on firearm and shotgun ownership for wildlife and countryside offences
attributes.background: Any person who is found guilty of offences under the Wildlife and Countryside Act should be automatically banned from ever owning a gun.  This would serve as an additional deterrent to those who continue to flout laws designed to protect British wildlife.
attributes.additional_details: Persecution of birds of prey is an ongoing problem within the British isles and those who carry it out appear to be doing so with impunity.  A conviction for breaching the Wildlife and Countryside Act is sufficient proof that an individual cannot be considered responsible enough to own these weapons and therefore a mandatory ban from owning them is a rational course of action and will serve as a more effective deterrent to those who might be inclined to offend.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban The Sale Of Disposable Barbecues.
attributes.background:
One Less Risk Of Harm. 

Ban the sale of disposable barbecues to help prevent the fires we've seen over the years in our National Parks.
attributes.additional_details:
Year after year fires in our National Parks caused by careless use of disposable barbecues. Fires have already started on a stretch of the Peak District and they will probably continue throughout the year. Another year of loss of valuable wildlife, another year of risk to people.

These fires are caused by humans and we need to minimise the damage that they can do by preventing disposable barbecues from being within easy reach of those who are unaware of, or choose to ignore the dangers they present to our wildlife, to civilians, and to our firefighters who have to put their lives at risk every time fires are started.

Let's all make this the year we have One Less Risk Of Harm to our National Parks, to the walking groups and families that enjoy them, and the wildlife that inhabit them.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Increase tax on fireworks to increase prices and fund related initiatives
attributes.background: The Government should increase taxes on fireworks, and use proceeds to fund veterinary fees for pets, livestock and wildlife that are directly affected by fireworks, and provide counselling for children and adults who are affected by fireworks noise.
attributes.additional_details:
Many pet, livestock owners, wildlife carers, forces veterans, children with special needs, OAP's, Parents of young children, people with special needs and others who hates loud noises want to have tighter restrictions.
 
The noise caused by fireworks can disrupt sleep and can cause distress and even death to animals. Ex-service men and woman who suffer from PTSD can also be adversely affected by the noise made by fireworks, and many OAPs are also scared of them.
 
We are all affected by this one way or another and would like something done sooner rather than later.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban all fireworks permanently, including displays.
attributes.background: Ban all fireworks in the UK permanently, to include firework displays. Public and private displays to be fully banned.
attributes.additional_details: Fireworks are dangerous, disruptive to lives and unsettling for many people, animals and wildlife. They cause extreme fear. They are excessively loud and set off at unsociable hours disturbing sleep. Firework remains are not pleasant to clean up, dangerous for our animals and wildlife if consumed, get stuck or tangled up.  Fireworks can cause horrific injuries which can be life changing or worse if handled incorrectly. They can be fatal to animals and wildlife.  They are not good for our environment. Please ban fireworks permanently.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Bring in legislation to end internal air flights in the UK.
attributes.background: A return flight London - Edinburgh produces 193kg of carbon emissions whilst the same journey by train produces only 24kg CO2. Ending internal flights when the journeys could be made without much inconvenience by far less polluting means, would significantly reduce the risks of the climate crisis.
attributes.additional_details: If left unabated the climate crisis will cause widespread suffering of people and wildlife, and economic loss. We need to half our carbon emissions by 2030 and then reduce them to net zero by 2050. The sooner we can change the way we live, adopting climate friendly habits, the easier it will be. The Government can play a major role in enabling and encouraging us to make these lifestyles changes, and to do so in a way that is fair to everyone.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Review the route and construction plans for HS2 for environmental reasons
attributes.background: Current plans for HS2 involve the destruction of woodlands and use of unsustainable building materials.
attributes.additional_details:
We want all ancient woodland left untouched and modern, environmentally friendly materials to be used, not materials like concrete.
 
This petition is not saying stop HS2, but is calling on the Government to review the route and construction plans for this project, because of the concerns of people who care about our environment and wildlife and we want to reduce the irreversible destruction to our ancient woodlands.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Bring the metaldehyde slug pellet ban forward to March 2021
attributes.background: Research proves that metaldehyde is a poison for wildlife, we can't allow another 18 months of damage to our countryside which includes at risk animals and already polluted soils. Please bring the date forward to 31 March 2021.
attributes.additional_details: On the 18th September 2020 the Government (for the second time) made the data and research led decision to ban the use of metaldehyde in the UK. Metaldehyde proven to kill wildlife. However the date of the ban is 31 March 2022, allowing another 18 months of damage to our countryside, which doesn't make sense. We know it's harmful, ban it now.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale, possession and importation of kangaroo meat, body parts and skins
attributes.background: We would like the Government to ban the sale, possession and importation of kangaroo meat, body parts, leather and skins in the UK. We request that the UK take a stand against the wildlife trade and legislate to prohibit all products originating from free ranging wild kangaroos.
attributes.additional_details: In the UK, killing animals by a non-mechanical percussive blow to the head is prohibited. When shooters kill kangaroos with pouch young, the code of practice requires a joey to be killed by decapitation or a concussive blow to the head. Shooters asked for guidance on killing pouch joeys, yet no training was offered. In 2019, an estimated 100,000 to 200,000 young died based on records of females killed. We believe the commercial killing of kangaroos breaches legislation and should be prohibited.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase penalties for the owners of dangerously out of control dogs
attributes.background: All pets, Wildlife & Live Stock should be provided the same protection under the Dangerous Dogs Act as Assistance Dogs.
attributes.additional_details:
Attacks on pets, wildlife and livestock by out of control dogs are common, and can result in injury, trauma and death. The Dangerous Dogs Act should be amended to increase penalties for owners who allow their dog to become dangerously out of control.

Animals deserve better protection. They must not be regarded as "property" and given the rights they deserve.

For many lost Animals including: 
Harry the Pomeranian attacked and Killed by 2 Dogs.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Extend the ban on microplastics to cover products such as sunscreen & cosmetics
attributes.background: In June 2018, microbeads in rinse-off products were banned in the UK, applying to products that immediately washed off after using them, such as toothpaste and face scrubs.  We would like to see the ban expanded to cover products that are applied and left on the skin, such as sunscreen & cosmetics.
attributes.additional_details: Whilst the current ban tackles rinse-off products, it does not cover products that are applied and left on the skin, such as sunscreen or cosmetics. This is despite the fact that sunscreens are applied before going for a swim. Over 75% of sunscreen products contain microplastic, and it's clear that the current ban on microplastics doesn't go far enough. Extending the ban to cover sunscreen and cosmetics would significantly reduce microplastic in our waterways, reducing impacts on wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban "Game" Bird Shooting now!
attributes.background: "Game" Bird shooting should be banned in England, for the sake of the animals and for those who love and care about the wildlife here. Many Britons are against trophy hunting of rhinos and lions, yet millions of birds are killed by hunters every year. It is done by the "game" shooting industry.
attributes.additional_details:
Right here, in the UK, around 47 million pheasants, and 10 million red-legged partridges, are released only to be shot for "sport" by the UK's wealthy. This is an absolute disgrace. It is unnecessary cruelty.
Many in the UK have a problem with non-native species, calling for grey squirrels to be killed. Yet, the shooting industry releases non-native species, and some gamekeepers kill native predators to "protect game birds".

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require all owners/occupiers of premises to keep their premises free of litter
attributes.background: Pass legislation which requires any individual or organisation responsible for premises to keep those premises tidy by clearing up litter as it occurs.
attributes.additional_details: Too many owners/occupiers allow their premises to become clogged with litter (whether dropped directly or windblown). Apart from being unsightly and a danger to wildlife, litter often blows from private premises onto public land, meaning that local authorities are faced with the expense of cleaning it up.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Stop culling badgers now
attributes.background: Stop culling badgers now
attributes.additional_details: Because I believe it has no effect, it’s barbaric, and we should be proud of and protect our wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban plastic charity bags being delivered to every household
attributes.background: Ban charities from using plastic bags to collect unwanted clothing and unwanted household items. The majority of households don’t use these bags for this purpose and it is just contributing to the mountain of plastic bag waste.
attributes.additional_details: These plastic charity bags are delivered without our permission and it is a national disgrace that we allow this to happen. Free plastic supermarket bags were banned in order to help save the environment and wildlife and so should plastic charity bags.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale and release of sky Lanterns & Balloons
attributes.background: Totally ban the sales and release of these products. Some local councils are taking action to tackle this but many people still let them off from their back gardens. Releasing these items causes harm to the environment, domestic animals, wildlife and farm stock.
attributes.additional_details: Common sense does not seem to work so the best thing to do is place an outright ban on these products.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Impose sanctions on Brazil due to unabated destruction of the Amazon
attributes.background: The Government should impose economic sanctions on Brazil to pressure its government to take action to halt deforestation. The 'lungs of the world' are being destroyed at an alarming rate, and the Bolsonaro administration has failed to limit legal deforestation or tackle illegal deforestation.
attributes.additional_details: We believe Bolsonaro has repeatedly ignored the concerns of the international community and had little regard for the indigenous population or the unique and spectacular wildlife that exists in the Amazon. In the midst of a climate emergency, the UK cannot sit back and watch this continued destruction without taking action.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Revoke Development Consent for the Riverside Energy Park in SE London
attributes.background: The Government should revoke the Development Consent Order for the Riverside Energy Park incinerator in South East London, to protect air quality, local wildlife, and the appearance of the area. The incinerator would be located near large populated urban areas.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Impose sanctions on countries involved in the illegal tiger trade
attributes.background: The commercial international trade in tigers and their parts has been banned since 1987, after a vote by the countries party to CITES, an international treaty regulating the wildlife trade.
attributes.additional_details:
The illegal trade of these majestic creatures continues in countries such as China, Thailand and Laos.
 
We implore the UK Government to use its political strength and global reach to put pressure on these countries to completely eradicate the destruction, torture and decimation of these beautiful, defenceless creatures.
 
This could be done by applying sanctions or trade restrictions.
 
Make the UK the leader in protecting the tiger!

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Make it illegal to import, sell or release sky lanterns
attributes.background: Ban the import and sale of sky lanterns, also known as 'Chinese lanterns', and make it an offence to set them off.
attributes.additional_details: We believe these pose a real threat because of the fire risk to property and injury to wildlife, plus the negative environmental impact of metal frames potentially littering the countryside.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban new housing developments in National Parks
attributes.background: The Government should stop all new housing developments in national parks across the UK. The New Forest authority is accepting plans for a new large development on national park land near Calshot. Developments like this should not be allowed.
attributes.additional_details: The impact on nature can be absolutely irreversible when major housing developments occur. Conserving nature and biodiversity should be of paramount importance to everyone. National parks are a haven for thousands of species, in some instances that are endemic to particular areas. This petition's values goes beyond economics, with a higher purpose of bio-conservation and the protection of wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Ban the production and use of domed lids on takeaway cups to protect wildlife
attributes.background: Domed lids are a hazard to wildlife. We have seen birds with their head stuck in the straw opening which prevented feeding and drinking, causing suffering, death by starvation, injury, infection, as well as making them an easy target for predators. These lids are potential death traps for wildlife.
attributes.additional_details: The lids are not a necessity and are often found littering open spaces. They are designed to accommodate whipped toppings on cold drinks but because they have a large opening to insert a straw, they also cause suffering and death in wildlife. The design needs to be revisited. In the meantime, please ban the production and use of these lids to protect our birds and wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove the "right to roam" status that domesticated cats are entitled to.
attributes.background: Update the law around domestic cats,  removing their "right to roam" status, putting the onus on cat owners to take responsibility for any nuisance to, or loss of enjoyment of, land, private property and wildlife.  Cats should fall under the same laws applying to dogs and other domesticated animals.
attributes.additional_details:
A: Cats kill an estimated 27 million birds/fledglings each breeding season (RSPB). We should be protecting our wildlife during a critical time for many species.  Two species they predate are in serious decline; House sparrows (71%) and Starlings (66%). The Mammal Society's Domestic Cats Predation on Wildlife research says 100 million prey items are taken by cats each season. 
B: Environmental protection laws being passed to save species, yet cats permitted to roam with the privilege to destroy.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Establish and Maintain an Aerial firefighting capability to combat wildfires
attributes.background: The United Kingdom is seeing a rise in record temperatures as a result of global warming. Whilst strategic measures are being taken to moderate these effects, tactically we need to establish a capability to fight heath and forest fires from the air.
attributes.additional_details: Global temperatures are rising and in the UK we have experienced record temperatures year on year and increasing levels of destruction of both wildlife habitat and property. It would be unfortunate if we did nothing to provide effective countermeasures until after the event. It takes about a year to convert a BAe 146 or similar aircraft to firefighting configuration so we could if we wanted to have capability in place for next summer.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Keep retained EU environmental laws until equal or stronger UK laws introduced
attributes.background: The Retained EU Law (Revocation & Reform) Bill will remove EU-derived law protecting air, water, wildlife, land and waste in 2023. We want these laws to be retained until replacement legislation is passed which delivers equal or stronger protection for nature than retained EU law.
attributes.additional_details: UK governments in the past decade have variously promised to be "the greenest government ever" and "to be the first generation that leaves the environment in a better state than that in which we inherited it". But the EU Law Bill risks creating a "gun-at-the-head" deadline for replacing retained EU law, rather than removing retained laws when Parliament has formulated and passed equal or stronger UK law. We believe spending valuable Parliamentary time on the latter would be the better option.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Don't close zoos, wildlife parks & rehabilitation centres.
attributes.background: In light of newly considerations re tighter national rules to combat COVID, I urge the government not to consider the closure of zoos, wildlife parks and rehabiltation centres, unless there is verifiable effidence that imcreased infections are linked to visits of such venues.
attributes.additional_details: Zoos, wildlife parks and rehabilitation centres have taken a significant financial impact that is still threatening the continuation of these businesses. These places provide vital contributions to maintain our natural environment, to prevent the extinction of endangered species, to help injured wildlife and educate about our natural world, on which we all rely. Their closure may lead to the death of animals and the loss of many jobs.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban the sale of disposable face masks to the general public
attributes.background: Make the sale and use of disposable masks to and for front line services only.
attributes.additional_details:
Disposable masks are being widely used and disposed of irresponsibly.  Cheap versions in small quantities  are being sold making them an attractive option for the public.  However they contain plastics, are non biodegradable and are causing suffering and death to wildlife.  They are being found littering the streets, beaches and in the sea.  They should be treated as hazardous waste just like any other medical waste.  
They contain polypropeline . 
Wildlife is suffering - getting trapped in strings. 
news.sky.com/story/coronavirus-disposable-face-masks-creating-new-plastic-pollution-crisis-experts-warn-12045350

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy
Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Work with councils to promote wildflower and grassland growth
attributes.background: The Government should work with local councils to promote the regrowth and rewilding of more green urban space.
attributes.additional_details:
This could involve reducing their grass mowing schedules. This could in turn have great effect on the populations of urban insects and mammals thus helping with wildlife right up the food chain.

I am very concerned about the state of urban greenspace. Though there are many wonderful designated greenspaces in urban areas there needs to be more focus on using all available land. For instance, the reduction of mowing on grass areas that do not need to be kept short would have a big impact. It would promote the growing of small wildflower and grassland areas all over urban areas. These would act as habitat and as migration routes for all manner of invertebrates and small mammals.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of Ant Gel Farms as part of the Animal Welfare Act 2006.
attributes.background: We want to ban the practice of unsuitable housing being promoted to the hobby of ant keeping. Gel farms and similar style ant farms, promote destruction of the local wildlife, their barbaric and not designed for the welfare of the creatures being kept, promoting poor husbandry practices.
attributes.additional_details: These nests promote damaging practices to the local wildlife, their not designed to care for the welfare of the creatures being housed, most often the Ants die a horrific death, drowning in the gel as it breaks down, becoming infested with mold and harmful bacteria, these are gimmick nests profiting from improper care and welfare practices.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of plastic manual toothbrushes in the UK by 2025.
attributes.background: We would like the government to ban the sale of manual plastic toothbrushes in the UK from 2025. Manual plastic toothbrushes are a prolific example of harmful plastic waste, and there are already a roster of viable alternatives on the market for industry to move forward with.
attributes.additional_details: Around 4.7 billion plastic manual toothbrushes are made each year. Each one of these is non-biodegradable. Even after 1000 years in landfill, these will reduce to smaller micro-plastics which are still dangerous to us and our wildlife. There are already viable alternatives, perhaps the most widely used being bamboo compostable toothbrushes. Bamboo suits well as it is quick growing and a sustainable wood to use in these quantities. We have proven that toothbrushes do not need to be harmful.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Take action to reduce cormorant numbers
attributes.background: Some studies have demonstrated that cormorants can have significant negative impacts on fish stocks. The wildlife license is not sufficient to solve this problem. Numbers are getting way out of hand, and fish stocks being affected as a result.
attributes.additional_details: The Government should temporarily lift the protected status of cormorants, to enable controlled reduction of numbers. The numbers of cormorants culled could be tracked, and protections reintroduced once numbers are reduced to manageable levels. Cormorant numbers should then be kept under review, to inform whether a further reduction in numbers is necessary.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Require specified levels of hedge planting for all new developments
attributes.background: Please set statutory requirements for every building erected and green/brown site built on, or cemented that sufficient hedging is planted for wildlife.
attributes.additional_details:
Developers are tearing down our environment at a great rate of knots.
Please write into constitutional law that all builders and developers MUST combat climate change by hedge (and/or) tree planting. They are quite happy to dodge loopholes on building local amenities i.e. schools by subcontracting, many have no social conscience. If you could please put in law that for every acre they decimate they must replant a portion of greenery to protect humans and wildlife from weathering and erosion, you do us all a favour. No trees, high winds. No food chain, issues.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Establish a presumption against felling of mature trees in England
attributes.background: We are losing native broadleaf trees at a tremendous rate. Felling can have massive impact on wildlife, biodiversity, environment, wellbeing and ultimately climate, yet few trees have Tree Preservation Orders, and there is little policy protection for the remainder.
attributes.additional_details: Policy needs to protect our tree resource and slow the decline of canopy cover. There is little point planting new trees if we continue cutting down mature trees. Young transplants cannot ‘replace’ the canopy of a single hundred-year old oak, and cannot provide significant benefit for years. How much simpler and more effective to retain existing habitats. A licence should be required for the felling of any mature tree, and be granted only in exceptional and clearly defined circumstances.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Do not remove special protection from vulnerable or near-threatened species
attributes.background: The Government must not remove special protections from species including red squirrels, pine martens, water voles, mountain hares, adders and slow-worms under the Wildlife and Countryside Act, 1981 (WCA), following its current review of the Act, reported in the press in July 2021.
attributes.additional_details: The Government reportedly plans to change the basis on which animals are protected under Schedules 5 and 8 of the WCA to exclude species which are vulnerable (at national or regional level) and near-threatened - see https://jncc.gov.uk/our-work/qqr-7/. It may suit property developers and infrastructure projects to exclude species not in imminent danger of extinction, but this risks harm to species which may be under severe threat, but whose populations have improved slightly.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban zoos and only permit wildlife sanctuaries that protect animal species
attributes.background: Animal species should be protected, not exploited. Animals should be safe and happy in sanctuaries, not zoos. The Government should ban zoos, and only permit wildlife sanctuaries, with higher animal welfare standards. This should result in more wildlife sanctuaries, with better habitats for animals.
attributes.additional_details: Animals are exploited for money and entertainment. They should be kept safe and happy with space to roam and live as they please, not showcased in a cage. Animals need space to live and should be given that. We believe animals in some zoos are not cared for adequately, and others are simply unhappy. Animals deserve to live in environments more similar to their natural habitats. We don't like isolation, why would they?

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of rat poison.
attributes.background: Killing rats with poison is inhumane and is unjust to wildlife that just happens to get in the way of humans.
attributes.additional_details: Ban rat poison.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Preserve diverse and mature woodlands in view of climate change.
attributes.background: To review policies concerning 'woodland management', in particular the PAWs restoration document in view of  the effects of climate change.
attributes.additional_details: The large scale removal of mature native and established none-native tree species from our mixed woodlands is not sustainable.  Woodland regeneration is slow and uncertain. Mature trees including conifer varieties have become established and play a vital role in the formation of twenty first century woodlands. I would ask the government to further protect existing woodlands in all their diversity for the benefit of people and wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of fireworks to protect animals
attributes.background:
Demand a complete ban on fireworks, animals are dieing because of them.
We're still commiting atrocities against animals and no one is doing any thing about this, they have rights in this world too.
attributes.additional_details:
I've had to bring my horses back from a horrendous 10 mins of horror, my mare run into a wooden fence when I had to put her out along with my pony he hasn't been well since. 

This all happens to wildlife also, there's sheep in lamb in the fields around us, the fireworks can make these farm animals abort their young. Horses die because of the stress, I've had this mostly every year for 10 years, enough is enough.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban plastic fishing nets in UK waters.
attributes.background: Plastic fishing gear discarded from vessels are polluting our seas and strangling wildlife. A truly biodegradable alternative needs to be rediscovered. Our oceans are a dumping ground for plastic and other rubbish; plastic fishing nets, ropes and other gear form a significant part of that pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Get plastic out of the sea, and stop any more unnecessary plastic waste including nets going into the seas. Persuade the fishing industry that fishing cannot be sustained with so much plastic waste in our oceans, including continued discarding of nets straggling and killing sea creatures.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Add a 'sustainability charge' on meat products to cover their environmental cost
attributes.background: Food production accounts for one-quarter of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions and takes up half of the planet’s habitable surface. The mass of animals raised for slaughter on Earth now outweighs wildlife by a factor of 15-to-1. One kilogram of beef needs about 15 thousand litres of water.
attributes.additional_details: By adding a 'sustainability charge' to meat products, this will encourage more conscious meat consumption. With this money going towards tackling climate change and renewable energy resources.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Require warning labels on palm oil products that are not produced sustainably
attributes.background: The Government should require products containing palm oil, where it has not been certified that this has been produced sustainably, to include labels showing the harm palm oil production causes, so consumers are made aware of this.
attributes.additional_details:
Palm oil is a huge contributor to deforestation in tropical climates, areas booming with wildlife, areas which many animals have called home for thousands of years. The deforestation caused by palm oil plantations have had a substantial negative impact on these areas, causing mass death and extinction of the animals living there. in Borneo, dozens orangutans are killed every week due to the production of palm oil.
This needs to end, and this is a start.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make it illegal for boats to discharge waste into rivers
attributes.background: Every year around July/August human waste can be seen where children swim & play in the river Ouse. Subject to local byelays boats can discharge waste directly into rivers. There is no need for this archaic danger to people and wildlife they should be pumped into waste units.
attributes.additional_details:
Although new boats are required to have a holding tank for waste, many boats simply discharge waste directly into the river. Every year from July to August human waste can be seen floating about where young children are swimming along the river Ouse.
 
To tackle this the Government should make it illegal for boats to discharge waste into rivers.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce a National Reforestation Scheme
attributes.background: Start a permanent reforestation scheme of planting locally appropriate tree species across the UK in all public owned spaces & incentivise planting on private land. Establish a panel of experts to recommend operational measures. Nominate a Gov't department to design and implement the scheme.
attributes.additional_details: Long term local and global  benefit of large scale diverse tree planting include: Improvement in quality of life for all, climate change prevention, creation of habitats for all wildlife, better air quality, prevention of flooding, a healthier population, prevention of loss of habitats and soil erosion and job creation. It is unethical to disregard this as it would be cheap and reasonable to start a scheme that could have a diverse and profound impact for the greater public good.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Send aid to Mauritius to help clear the oil spill.
attributes.background: The UK has experienced oil spills in the past and know the catastrophic effects that it can cause to the biodiversity of native wildlife. Resources within Mauritius to clear an oil spill of this size are limited and, therefore, aiding the country to clear the spill is essential.
attributes.additional_details: From our history of oil spills, such as the Torrey Canyon disaster in 1967 spilling 119,000 tonnes of crude oil, we are able to provide expertise, equipment and solutions to the communities who are working to contain and clear the oil spill. This is needed to be done sooner rather than later due to the disastrous effects it can cause on the environment as well as the country’s economy that strongly relies on tourism, due to its pristine coasts.

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Phase out the usage of gill nets within UK waters
attributes.background: This petition calls upon the UK government to commit to the phasing out of gill nets within a clear time frame and meet their commitment in the post-Brexit Fisheries Act to “minimise and where possible eliminate” dolphin, porpoise and whale bycatch from UK fishing activities.
attributes.additional_details:
Gillnets, fixed fishing nets which are anchored to the seabed, are one of the greatest threats toward cetacean species and responsible for approximately 1000 porpoise and 250 dolphin deaths each year

Though greatly harmful to marine mammals, the use of these nets only make up 2% (!) of fishery catches. 

The phasing out of the usage of this equipment will do masses to help protect marine wildlife with minimal disruption to the fishing industry.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban sale and use of Leaf Blowers
attributes.background: Ban the sale and use of leaf blowers throughout the UK. They are noisy, polluting, can kill small animals, and can easily be replaced with more quiet, environmentally friendly gardening tools.
attributes.additional_details:
Petrol powered leaf blowers can emit massive amounts of pollution - hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides as well as carbon monoxide.

Even when electric alternatives are used, they cause noise disturbance and distress to both people and wildlife. Additionally, many small animals can be injured or killed due to leaf blowing, in particular insects.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Revoke the Invasive Alien Species Order 2019
attributes.background: Stop the culling of Grey Squirrels and Montjacks and other similar species.
attributes.additional_details:
Grey Squirrels and Montjacks were introduced to the UK by man many many years ago and now form part of our wildlife and should be protected. 

We live in a rural area and enjoy seeing these animals.
